channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Surveillance footage from Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, shows officers retreating from gunfire and waiting for 77 minutes before confronting the gunman. The delayed police response has been widely criticized and is under investigation. https://t.co/y0WJ2nCFOS https://t.co/M1Ihcny5LW

A judge in Colorado issued an arrest warrant for Tina Peters, the Mesa County clerk accused of overseeing a breach of election equipment after the 2020 election, for violating conditions of her bond that prevented her from traveling without court approval. https://t.co/vX6ShJv5qO

Breaking News: Alex Murdaugh, a powerful South Carolina lawyer, was charged with killing his wife and one of his sons in a mysterious murder that remained unsolved for more than a year. https://t.co/Z8e1sWZmID

We spent the past months speaking to over 30 millennials from around the U.S. about their finances. Their anxieties were palpable, and painfully familiar — many of them felt behind, indebted and unable to live up to the expectations placed upon them. https://t.co/nDXTw0jCml https://t.co/BxTNss6neX

The Biden administration warned pharmacies that they risk violating civil rights law if they refuse to dispense pills that can induce abortion. Withholding the pills “may be discriminating” on the basis of sex or disability, officials said. https://t.co/VRcbdJ0Pia

Gasoline prices in the U.S. have declined 28 days in a row — the longest decline since early 2020, offering some relief to drivers. Weather, war and demand will help shape whether the decline can be sustained. https://t.co/pmgmNxnOGk
The symptoms of coronavirus subvariants BA.4 and BA.5 are similar to those of earlier versions of Omicron, experts said. https://t.co/99LjLvFADJ https://t.co/Ss3MlYyck5

Two men and a woman were arrested in Hornell, New York, after white supremacist literature was found across the small city, including at a Black church and a synagogue.
The suspects were each charged with 115 counts of a hate crime, one for each leaflet. https://t.co/H8wO8ncZxk

The House on Wednesday passed a bill that would make millions of veterans who were exposed to trash burn pits on U.S. military bases around the world eligible for medical care. https://t.co/4RRBA4UIe9

As outrage mounts over Brittney Griner's continued detention, the WNBA star has become a living symbol of the limits of American power — and of the U.S. government’s finite ability to protect its citizens abroad, writes Amanda Taub. https://t.co/axU0ZKYnEW

Grizzly Giant, a more than 2,000-year-old sequoia in Yosemite National Park, has been threatened by the Washburn fire. Officials hope a sprinkler system can help save it.
“We have to go to the ends of the earth to protect this tree,” one ecologist said. https://t.co/WACbErT3IJ

1. The telescope works really, really well. 2. We’ll see deeper into the universe’s past than ever. 3. We’ll uncover the atmospheres of distant planets. 4. We’ll discover the unexpected.
Here's what we learned from the Webb telescope's first five images. https://t.co/NO371DJpAL

For the first time in a New York Times/Siena College national survey, Democrats won a larger share of white college graduates than nonwhite voters. See the full breakdown here. https://t.co/ChTaGLAnsf https://t.co/tSyKLse4Ih

Mary McLeod Bethune on Wednesday became the first Black American to be represented with a state statue in National Statuary Hall, a central room of the U.S. Capitol, honored for her work championing education and civil rights. https://t.co/bzBwPEW6pc https://t.co/qyVDmKEGs8

An Ohio man was arrested and charged with the rape of a 10-year-old girl, who traveled across state lines for an abortion. Before the arrest, some conservatives, including Ohio’s top prosecutor, and a Wall Street Journal editorial, cast doubt on the case. https://t.co/9FjD61ez7Y

Mary McLeod Bethune was said to start a school in 1904 with $1.50. The school grew into Bethune-Cookman University by 2007, and on Wednesday she became the first Black American to be represented with a state statue at the Capitol’s National Statuary Hall. https://t.co/iCthjDL9YW
Breaking News: A former CIA software engineer was convicted of causing the largest theft of classified information in the agency’s history. https://t.co/TNJs0GgnIw
Lemon zest, lemon juice, Parmesan and basil come together for a silky and vibrant sauce that makes this weeknight-friendly pasta sing. https://t.co/FQhuC550Ox https://t.co/X4DqciFRuo

Ray Epps was taped before Jan. 6 urging people to go to the Capitol. Then he became the face of a conspiracy theory by pro-Trump forces that the FBI was behind the riot. Since then, he's been forced to sell his home and his business — and go into hiding. https://t.co/3vq4TVmpC9
Breaking News: U.S. prices in June climbed 9.1% from last year, the fastest pace since 1981, as gas prices, rent and grocery bills continued to soar. https://t.co/IHM9jUUDPV

The euro fell to “parity” with the U.S. dollar for the first time in two decades. Pressure on the euro has been mounting while investors have been flocking to the dollar, a haven in times of economic upheaval. https://t.co/TYA0uBKNRs https://t.co/cbb6KD2L66

Stephan’s Quintet is a snippet of the night sky that looks unreal — five galaxies that appear to be almost touching each other. A new Webb telescope image gives a closer look. https://t.co/EA07s9Dws6 https://t.co/iw8MR7yelw

Steve Martin and Martin Short were both just nominated for an Emmy — in the same category. @ditzkoff asked them: Have they ever been in direct competition before?
"Just emotionally," Short said. "Every minute of every day," Martin added. https://t.co/xym53jWhtw

The James Webb Space Telescope, the most powerful space telescope yet built, on Tuesday offered a spectacular slide-show of our previously invisible nascent cosmos, giving a "new meaning to 'as far as the eye can see.'" https://t.co/UJz2eTKr7o https://t.co/0VBhy9Kwiv

The Jan. 6 committee played a recording of Representative Debbie Lesko — among those who led objections to the election results — predicting that Trump supporters were “going to go nuts” once they realized that Congress would not overturn the election. https://t.co/RJbDystQ10 https://t.co/G1Cnb4lsuK

Brandy Bottone of Plano, Texas, was issued a $275 ticket for driving alone in a high-occupancy vehicle lane while in her third trimester of pregnancy. She said she was looking forward to her court date on July 20, two weeks before her baby is due. https://t.co/OKsENHCrch
Calling, texting or emailing a friend just to say “hello” might seem like an insignificant gesture, but it can have a powerful effect, new research suggests. https://t.co/ommTg0ivra

In Tuesday’s hearing, Rep. Jamie Raskin underscored how white nationalism became intertwined with the "stop the steal" movement before Jan. 6, reading messages that cited a white supremacist novel culminating in mass hangings of perceived “race traitors.” https://t.co/vXuZe4PDAs https://t.co/QBwWaBdU9w

Testimony by Katrina Pierson, a former Trump spokeswoman, was featured prominently in Tuesday's Jan. 6 hearing. She testified that Donald Trump "loved people who viciously defended him" — people whom she called "crazies" in a 2020 text message. https://t.co/6LWIY0SXhT https://t.co/JP8MmyIJm8
Breaking News: A judge in Louisiana temporarily blocked the state’s abortion bans for the second time, allowing the procedure to become legal again. https://t.co/uRyxlk6N8h

Rep. Liz Cheney said on Tuesday that the Jan. 6 committee had been told that Donald Trump had reached out in the last two weeks to a witness in the panel’s investigation, and that the committee had informed the Justice Department of the approach. https://t.co/bIfzuxZqcu https://t.co/ttDm95a2Fk
"Squid Game" made history on Tuesday. https://t.co/CofzpwT54x https://t.co/lOWwXBQKqX

Rep. Liz Cheney said on Tuesday that the Jan. 6 committee had been told that Donald Trump had reached out in the last two weeks to a witness in the panel’s investigation, and that the committee had informed the Justice Department of the approach. https://t.co/WLx359K4AT

Twitter sued Elon Musk on Tuesday to force the billionaire to complete his $44 billion acquisition of the company, setting the stage for a prolonged legal battle. https://t.co/lUrOQtLm5u https://t.co/nJEcUjD866
Breaking News: Twitter sued Elon Musk to force him to complete his $44 billion purchase of the company, setting up a prolonged legal battle. https://t.co/nCU2Q7FonJ

Senator Joe Manchin, a West Virginia Democrat who has taken more campaign contributions from oil, gas and coal companies than any other senator, has assailed proposed tax incentives for electric vehicles as unnecessary and wasteful. https://t.co/xZ2VUzPKKD

“President Trump is a 76-year-old man. He is not an impressionable child.”
In Tuesday's hearing, Representative Liz Cheney gave a harsh assessment of attempts to excuse President Trump’s behavior leading up to the Jan. 6 Capitol attack. https://t.co/kBBUum16j5 https://t.co/wPp9sq2y4u

The Carina Nebula is home to some of the most luminous and potentially explosive stars in the galaxy. Amber Straughn, deputy project scientist for the James Webb Space Telescope, says the photo shows "hundreds of new stars that we've never seen before." https://t.co/bUgfKqTKSM https://t.co/XWkziGHiQO

About 4,000 beagles were rescued from a breeding and research facility in Virginia that broke regulations and left the animals underfed, ill and injured.
Now the authorities have about two months to find the dogs new homes. https://t.co/AGT3qiJmaY

From @TheAthletic
Why did one of the greatest quarterback prospects of all time walk away from the game before turning 30?
Inside the Andrew Luck story that has never been told. https://t.co/YGF3oiKZmT https://t.co/tnmLupAhBS
Breaking News: Donald Trump planned ahead of Jan. 6 to march to the Capitol but wanted it to look like a spontaneous decision, witnesses testified on Tuesday. Follow live. https://t.co/U0EGVG9ry3

The James Webb Space Telescope's Deep Field image showed a distant patch of sky in which fledgling galaxies were burning their way into visibility just 600 million years after the Big Bang. https://t.co/JMeSZqtrpn https://t.co/91T30057CB

The Southern Ring Nebula began when a star shuddered and died, launching its own atmosphere into space like an expanding soap bubble. The part of the star left behind was a scalding-hot core, white dwarf, centered in the James Webb Telescope's image. https://t.co/tpyzrVDbPj https://t.co/8U5IAvrpnR

The Carina Nebula is a turbulent cloud of gas and dust about 7,600 light-years from Earth. The James Webb telescope captured the birthplace and graveyard for some of the Milky Way’s hottest and most massive stars. https://t.co/dgmUFLCGcr https://t.co/UyD4UY8aMQ

The James Webb Telescope's snippet of Stephan's Quintet has five galaxies that appear to almost touch. The image gives a clearer view of the tails and loops of gas and stars in the four distant galaxies and bright emissions of X-rays from diffuse hot gas. https://t.co/4vrkZ9edkG https://t.co/JtlEEF8eb2

"I ate this whole thing by myself. All of it," commented one reader.
This unfussy cake with a top layer of jammy strawberries is so gooey it’s best to serve the whole thing with a spoon. https://t.co/bUsFUFRHzZ https://t.co/UjmBfdhfPs

Starting July 16, people in the U.S. who are experiencing mental distress will be able to dial just three numbers to reach the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline. Employees and volunteers staffing the 24-hour hotline will be trained counselors. https://t.co/IQH2sLjQcN https://t.co/siiEUfuYJb

As many as a thousand demonstrators gathered in front of the Zhengzhou branch of China's central bank to demand their money back after it was frozen by the authorities amid allegations of financial fraud. https://t.co/C3hbh4uJXQ https://t.co/xlymbdUFfz

NASA and its team of astronomers and science outreach experts selected the images to be released today to show off the power of the James Webb Space Telescope — the largest space observatory ever built.
Follow our live updates as the photos are revealed: https://t.co/0G3Tg8UUH4

Mo Farah, the first British track and field athlete to win four Olympic gold medals, said that he had been trafficked to the UK as a child under a false name.
“Most people know me as Mo Farah, but it’s not my name, or it’s not the reality,” he said. https://t.co/ZjTz87vGZF https://t.co/SJWZQYRAhV
